definition: King Huai of Chu (reigned 328-299 BC)/later King Huai of Chu (reigned 208-205 BC)
distinct/clear/orderly/pain/suffering/deciduous bush used in Chinese medicine (genus Vitex)/punishment cane (old)
surname Chu/abbr. for Hubei 湖北省[Hu2 bei3 Sheng3] and Hunan 湖南省[Hu2 nan2 Sheng3] provinces together/Chinese kingdom during the Spring and Autumn and Warring States Periods (722-221 BC)
bosom/heart/mind/to think of/to harbor in one's mind/to conceive (a child)
surname Huai
surname Wang
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
to rule/to reign over
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
King Min of Qi (reigned 323-284 BC)
King Huiwen of Qin 秦國|秦国, ruled 338-211 BC during the Warring States Period
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Duke Mu of Qin, the first substantial king of Qin (ruled 659-621 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
King Huiwen of Zhao 趙國|赵国, reigned 298-266 BC during the Warring States Period
Qi state of Western Zhou and the Warring states (1122-265 BC), centered in Shandong
Zhao, one of the seven states during the Warring States Period of Chinese history (475-220 BC)
Xiang Yu the Conqueror (232-202 BC), warlord defeated by first Han emperor
King Xuan of Qi (reigned 342-324 BC)

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
Wei State (407-225 BC), one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Wei State or Cao Wei 曹魏 (220-265), the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms
Duke Xiao of Qin, 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], ruled 361-338 BC during the Warring States Period
Wu Zixu (-484 BC), powerful politician in Wu/famous as destitute refugee begging in Wu town, cf 吳市吹簫|吴市吹箫
